elements.content: In this paper, a photochromic diarylethene-based derivative that is coordinatively immobilized within an extended porphyrin framework is shown to maintain its photoswitchable behavior and to direct the photophysical properties of the host. In particular, emission of a framework composed of bis(5-pyridyl-2-methyl-3-thienyl)cyclopentene (BPMTC) and tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin (H4TCPP) ligands anchored by Zn2+ ions can be altered as a function of incident light. We attribute the observed cyclic fluorescence behavior of the synthesized porphyrin–BPMTC array to activation of energy transfer (ET) pathways through BPMTC photoisomerization. Time-resolved photoluminescence measurements show a decrease in average porphyrin emission lifetime upon BPMTC insertion, consistent with an ET-based mechanism. These studies portend the possible utilization of photochromic ligands to direct chromophore behavior in large light-harvesting ensembles.
elements.clean_text: In this paper, a photochromic diarylethene-based derivative that is coordinatively immobilized within an extended porphyrin framework is shown to maintain its photoswitchable behavior and to direct the photophysical properties of the host. In particular, emission of a framework composed of bis(5-pyridyl-2-methyl-3-thienyl)cyclopentene (BPMTC) and tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin (H4TCPP) ligands anchored by Zn2+ ions can be altered as a function of incident light. We attribute the observed cyclic fluorescence behavior of the synthesized porphyrin-BPMTC array to activation of energy transfer (ET) pathways through BPMTC photoisomerization. Time-resolved photoluminescence measurements show a decrease in average porphyrin emission lifetime upon BPMTC insertion, consistent with an ET-based mechanism. These studies portend the possible utilization of photochromic ligands to direct chromophore behavior in large light-harvesting ensembles.

elements.content: Mimics of light harvesting in the natural photosystem necessitate an assembly of highly ordered chlorophyll-like chromophores for efficient light absorption with the possibility of excitation-energy funneling along a predesigned pathway. In the natural system, the high efficiency of solar energy utilization is contingent on ensemble chromophore behavior. Typically, a reaction center in a photosystem is surrounded by ∼200 chlorophylls, emphasizing the utility of the molecular self-assembly process for effective design of artificial light-harvesting arrays. Such control of chromophore arrangement can be achieved in metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) through ligand-to-metal coordination. Furthermore, MOFs show a high degree of structural and chemical tunability, imposing very few restrictions on the chromophore of choice. The feasibility of using MOFs as light-harvesting antennas was recently demonstrated with porphyrin-containing frameworks, in which long-distance energy migration was detected. In line with these studies, previous investigations of energy migration dynamics showed fluorescence quenching via metal-to-metal energy transfer (ET) in Ru(Os)-containing MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Mimics of light harvesting in the natural photosystem necessitate an assembly of highly ordered chlorophyll-like chromophores for efficient light absorption with the possibility of excitation-energy funneling along a predesigned pathway. In the natural system, the high efficiency of solar energy utilization is contingent on ensemble chromophore behavior. Typically, a reaction center in a photosystem is surrounded by ~200 chlorophylls, emphasizing the utility of the molecular self-assembly process for effective design of artificial light-harvesting arrays. Such control of chromophore arrangement can be achieved in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) through ligand-to-metal coordination. Furthermore, MOFs show a high degree of structural and chemical tunability, imposing very few restrictions on the chromophore of choice. The feasibility of using MOFs as light-harvesting antennas was recently demonstrated with porphyrin-containing frameworks, in which long-distance energy migration was detected. In line with these studies, previous investigations of energy migration dynamics showed fluorescence quenching via metal-to-metal energy transfer (ET) in Ru(Os)-containing MOFs.

elements.content: Photochromic compounds capable of switching between two discrete states upon photoirradiation could be potentially utilized to control the photophysical properties of molecules coupled to the switch. This approach was previously implemented in molecular donor–acceptor (D–A) dyads, in which a photoswitchable A provided control of D excited states by ET. Those studies provided us with insight that coupling of chromophores with photoswitchable ligands could be feasible in extended structures such as MOFs. Previously, photoswitchable molecules were incorporated into MOFs to affect the porosity and gas sorption properties. As a result of D–A pairing inside a framework, the photophysical properties of a MOF may be controlled as a function of incident light, and in particular, photoswitchable linkers could direct chromophore behavior of light-harvesting ensembles (Scheme ). This strategy, which is a concept missing from the natural photosystem, provides the possibility of dynamic control of the ET in extended light-harvesting matrices.

This approach was previously implemented in molecular donor-acceptor (D-A) dyads, in which a photoswitchable A provided control of D excited states by ET. Those studies provided us with insight that coupling of chromophores with photoswitchable ligands could be feasible in extended structures such as MOFs. Previously, photoswitchable molecules were incorporated into MOFs to affect the porosity and gas sorption properties. As a result of D-A pairing inside a framework, the photophysical properties of a MOF may be controlled as a function of incident light, and in particular, photoswitchable linkers could direct chromophore behavior of light-harvesting ensembles (Scheme ). This strategy, which is a concept missing from the natural photosystem, provides the possibility of dynamic control of the ET in extended light-harvesting matrices.

elements.content: Herein we prove the hypothesis shown in Scheme that coordinative immobilization of a photochromic ligand, bis(5-pyridyl-2-methyl-3-thienyl)cyclopentene (BPMTC), in a porphyrin framework can direct the excited-state decay pathway of a porphyrin-based MOF. Time-resolved photoluminescence (PL) measurements were employed to monitor changes in the MOF photophysical behavior and provide estimates of the ET rate and efficiency.
elements.clean_text: Herein we prove the hypothesis shown in Scheme  that coordinative immobilization of a photochromic ligand, bis(5-pyridyl-2-methyl-3-thienyl)cyclopentene (BPMTC), in a porphyrin framework can direct the excited-state decay pathway of a porphyrin-based MOF. Time-resolved photoluminescence (PL) measurements were employed to monitor changes in the MOF photophysical behavior and provide estimates of the ET rate and efficiency.

elements.content: Among the variety of photochromic molecules, diaryl­ethene-based compounds were chosen for immobilization inside the MOF matrix because of their fatigue-resistant photochromic performance. Moreover, diarylethene derivatives are thermally stable and exhibit rapid response in the solid state. For incorporation into a framework, a diarylethene-based core was modified with two pyridyl arms to facilitate coordination to a metal center (Scheme ). The photochromic molecule of choice dictates the selection of the paired photoluminescent MOF, which should satisfy two main criteria. First, the emission spectrum of the MOF (D) should overlap with the absorption spectrum of the closed form of BPMTC (A) for effective resonance energy transfer (RET). Second, the emissive framework should possess accessible metal sites for efficient BPMTC pillar installation. The two-dimensional (2D) framework Zn2(ZnTCPP) [H4TCPP = tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin] satisfies both requirements. Figure demonstrates that Zn2(ZnTCPP) is emissive in the range of 600–700 nm with an emission maximum of 652 nm (λex = 590 nm). As a result, the fluorescence spectrum of Zn2(ZnTCPP) overlaps with the absorption profile of BPMTC in the closed form but does not overlap with the absorption spectrum of the photoswitch in the open form (Figure ). Thus, irradiation of the Zn2(ZnTCPP)–BPMTC framework with UV or visible light could result in quenching or enhancement of the MOF fluorescence, respectively (Scheme ). Furthermore, Zn2(ZnTCPP) also fulfills the second criterion (vide supra). Its structure consists of 2D sheets made from paddlewheel Zn2(O2C−)4 secondary building units (SBUs) bridged by ZnTCPP4– ligands [Figures S1 and S2 in the (SI)]. Each SBU contains two Zn atoms with axially coordinated solvent molecules, which can be replaced with pyridine-containing pillars.
elements.clean_text: Among the variety of photochromic molecules, diarylethene-based compounds were chosen for immobilization inside the MOF matrix because of their fatigue-resistant photochromic performance. Moreover, diarylethene derivatives are thermally stable and exhibit rapid response in the solid state. For incorporation into a framework, a diarylethene-based core was modified with two pyridyl arms to facilitate coordination to a metal center (Scheme ). The photochromic molecule of choice dictates the selection of the paired photoluminescent MOF, which should satisfy two main criteria. First, the emission spectrum of the MOF (D) should overlap with the absorption spectrum of the closed form of BPMTC (A) for effective resonance energy transfer (RET). Second, the emissive framework should possess accessible metal sites for efficient BPMTC pillar installation. The two-dimensional (2D) framework Zn2(ZnTCPP) [H4TCPP = tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin] satisfies both requirements. Figure  demonstrates that Zn2(ZnTCPP) is emissive in the range of 600-700 nm with an emission maximum of 652 nm (λex = 590 nm). As a result, the fluorescence spectrum of Zn2(ZnTCPP) overlaps with the absorption profile of BPMTC in the closed form but does not overlap with the absorption spectrum of the photoswitch in the open form (Figure ). Thus, irradiation of the Zn2(ZnTCPP)-BPMTC framework with UV or visible light could result in quenching or enhancement of the MOF fluorescence, respectively (Scheme ). Furthermore, Zn2(ZnTCPP) also fulfills the second criterion (vide supra). Its structure consists of 2D sheets made from paddlewheel Zn2(O2C-)4 secondary building units (SBUs) bridged by ZnTCPP4- ligands [Figures S1 and S2 in the  (SI)]. Each SBU contains two Zn atoms with axially coordinated solvent molecules, which can be replaced with pyridine-containing pillars.

elements.content: Diffuse reflectance (DR) spectra of BPMTC in the closed (blue trace) and open (black trace) forms, normalized to a value of 1.0 at 339 nm. Gray lines correspond to DR spectra collected during irradiation of BPMTC at 365 nm. The red trace depicts the normalized emission spectrum of Zn2(ZnTCPP) (λex = 590 nm). The inset shows a photograph of BPMTC after irradiation at 365 and 590 nm.
elements.clean_text: 1  Diffuse reflectance (DR) spectra of BPMTC in the closed (blue trace) and open (black trace) forms, normalized to a value of 1.0 at 339 nm. Gray lines correspond to DR spectra collected during irradiation of BPMTC at 365 nm. The red trace depicts the normalized emission spectrum of Zn2(ZnTCPP) (λex = 590 nm). The inset shows a photograph of BPMTC after irradiation at 365 and 590 nm.

elements.content: Before its coordinative immobilization inside a MOF matrix, the photochromic properties of the prepared BPMTC were studied in the solid state. It was found that BPMTC changed color from white to blue after irradiation at 365 nm (Figure ), indicating conversion from the open form to the closed form. The reverse process was detected during irradiation at 590 nm. After confirmation of the solid-state photochromic behavior, BPMTC was immobilized between 2D Zn2(ZnTCPP) layers by solvothermal synthesis (see the ). This reaction produced red square plates of [Zn2(ZnTCPP)(BPMTC)0.85(DEF)1.15]·(DEF)5.15(H2O)7.25 (1) (DEF = N,N-diethylformamide). The size of the obtained crystals was sufficient for single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis. However, several attempts using synchrotron radiation were necessary to collect a data set of sufficient quality, which to a certain extent may be explained by the photoswitchable nature of BPMTC and/or partial pillar insertion. The latter facts prevented the assignment of the residual electron density to the disordered BPMTC molecules (for more details, see the ). However, X-ray analysis undoubtedly revealed the positions of the Zn2(ZnTCPP) layers, and all of the C, N, and Zn atoms were refined anisotropically. As shown in Figure , the unit cell parameter c increases from 18.5799(15) to 29.890(9) Å, indicating a change in the interlayer distance from 2.82 to 14.71 Å in going from Zn2(ZnTCPP) to 1 (). More importantly, this interlayer expansion is consistent with the size of the BPMTC pillar (). Indeed, the N···N distances in BPMTC and its analogues are in the range of 14.46–15.41 Å depending on molecular conformation (). Thereby, BPMTC bridges two Zn atoms in 1: one Zn from a Zn2(O2C−)4 SBU in one layer and the core Zn of a ZnTCPP4– porphyrin in a different layer (). As a consequence, the pillar insertion results in a change in the layer stacking from ABAB to ABBA in going from Zn2(ZnTCPP) to 1 but preserves a tetragonal crystal system (Figures and and ). Notably, the pillar insertion does not affect the unit cell parameters a and b, whose values are similar in Zn2(ZnTCPP) [16.694(1) Å] and 1 [16.710(3) Å]. Powder XRD (PXRD), mass spectrometry (MS), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), elemental analysis (EA), and 1H NMR, IR, and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy were employed to study as-synthesized bulk 1 (Figures and ). The PXRD pattern of 1 coincided with the simulated one from the single-crystal X-ray studies (Figure ). Comparison with the PXRD data for Zn2(ZnTCPP) indicated a peak shift toward lower 2θ in the PXRD pattern of 1 associated with interlayer expansion and therefore BPMTC insertion. The combination of 1H NMR and EDX spectroscopy, MS, and EA clearly indicated that 1 is composed of H4TCPP and BPMTC ligands in a 1:0.85 ratio ().
elements.clean_text: Before its coordinative immobilization inside a MOF matrix, the photochromic properties of the prepared BPMTC were studied in the solid state. It was found that BPMTC changed color from white to blue after irradiation at 365 nm (Figure ), indicating conversion from the open form to the closed form. The reverse process was detected during irradiation at 590 nm. After confirmation of the solid-state photochromic behavior, BPMTC was immobilized between 2D Zn2(ZnTCPP) layers by solvothermal synthesis (see the ). This reaction produced red square plates of [Zn2(ZnTCPP)(BPMTC)0.85(DEF)1.15]⋅(DEF)5.15(H2O)7.25 (1) (DEF = N,N-diethylformamide). The size of the obtained crystals was sufficient for single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis. However, several attempts using synchrotron radiation were necessary to collect a data set of sufficient quality, which to a certain extent may be explained by the photoswitchable nature of BPMTC and/or partial pillar insertion. The latter facts prevented the assignment of the residual electron density to the disordered BPMTC molecules (for more details, see the ). However, X-ray analysis undoubtedly revealed the positions of the Zn2(ZnTCPP) layers, and all of the C, N, and Zn atoms were refined anisotropically. As shown in Figure , the unit cell parameter c increases from 18.5799(15) to 29.890(9) Å, indicating a change in the interlayer distance from 2.82 to 14.71 Å in going from Zn2(ZnTCPP) to 1 (). More importantly, this interlayer expansion is consistent with the size of the BPMTC pillar (). Indeed, the N⋅⋅⋅N distances in BPMTC and its analogues are in the range of 14.46-15.41 Å depending on molecular conformation (). Thereby, BPMTC bridges two Zn atoms in 1: one Zn from a Zn2(O2C-)4 SBU in one layer and the core Zn of a ZnTCPP4- porphyrin in a different layer (). As a consequence, the pillar insertion results in a change in the layer stacking from ABAB to ABBA in going from Zn2(ZnTCPP) to 1 but preserves a tetragonal crystal system (Figures  and  and ). Notably, the pillar insertion does not affect the unit cell parameters a and b, whose values are similar in Zn2(ZnTCPP) [16.694(1) Å] and 1 [16.710(3) Å]. Powder XRD (PXRD), mass spectrometry (MS), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), elemental analysis (EA), and 1H NMR, IR, and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy were employed to study as-synthesized bulk 1 (Figures  and ). The PXRD pattern of 1 coincided with the simulated one from the single-crystal X-ray studies (Figure ). Comparison with the PXRD data for Zn2(ZnTCPP) indicated a peak shift toward lower 2θ in the PXRD pattern of 1 associated with interlayer expansion and therefore BPMTC insertion. The combination of 1H NMR and EDX spectroscopy, MS, and EA clearly indicated that 1 is composed of H4TCPP and BPMTC ligands in a 1:0.85 ratio ().

elements.content: PXRD patterns of 1 and simulated Zn2(ZnTCPP) (preferential orientation along the 00l direction). The dashed arrow indicates the changes in the PXRD profile associated with the increase in the interlayer distance. The inset shows the 2D → 3D transformation by BPMTC insertion. The unit cell parameters of Zn2(ZnTCPP) and 1 were determined by single-crystal X-ray crystallography.
elements.clean_text: 2  PXRD patterns of 1 and simulated Zn2(ZnTCPP) (preferential orientation along the 00l direction). The dashed arrow indicates the changes in the PXRD profile associated with the increase in the interlayer distance. The inset shows the 2D → 3D transformation by BPMTC insertion. The unit cell parameters of Zn2(ZnTCPP) and 1 were determined by single-crystal X-ray crystallography.

elements.content: To test whether BPMTC could preserve its photoswitchable behavior after coordinative immobilization and therefore affect the photophysical properties of 1, a sample of 1 was illuminated with light at two wavelengths, 365 and 590 nm, which drove opening and closing of the BPMTC switch, respectively. During each transition, the emission spectrum was recorded to determine relative PL intensity changes. As anticipated, irradiation at 365 nm resulted in attenuation of the PL from 1 (Figures and ) caused by BPMTC photoisomerization from the initially open form to the closed form. We found that the fluorescence intensity was restored to the original value after irradiation at 590 nm (Figure ). As a control experiment, the fluorescence response from Zn2(ZnTCPP), which does not contain the photoswitchable BPMTC, was recorded at λex = 365 and 590 nm (Figure ). As expected, there was no enhancement or decay of the fluorescence intensity during irradiation. Furthermore, after several consecutive cycles of alternating 365 nm and 590 nm irradiation, 1 preserved its photoswitchable behavior (). However, fluorescence decay and enhancement were observed to occur at different rates (). For instance, a sample of 1 irradiated at 365 nm for 30 min required 107 min of irradiation at 590 nm to regain its fluorescence response (Figure ). This fact is consistent with the photoisomerization rates that we observed for noncoordinated BPMTC in the solid state. Indeed, conversion of BPMTC from the closed form to the open form under 590 nm irradiation is ∼45 times slower than the reverse process.
elements.clean_text: To test whether BPMTC could preserve its photoswitchable behavior after coordinative immobilization and therefore affect the photophysical properties of 1, a sample of 1 was illuminated with light at two wavelengths, 365 and 590 nm, which drove opening and closing of the BPMTC switch, respectively. During each transition, the emission spectrum was recorded to determine relative PL intensity changes. As anticipated, irradiation at 365 nm resulted in attenuation of the PL from 1 (Figures  and ) caused by BPMTC photoisomerization from the initially open form to the closed form. We found that the fluorescence intensity was restored to the original value after irradiation at 590 nm (Figure ). As a control experiment, the fluorescence response from Zn2(ZnTCPP), which does not contain the photoswitchable BPMTC, was recorded at λex = 365 and 590 nm (Figure ). As expected, there was no enhancement or decay of the fluorescence intensity during irradiation. Furthermore, after several consecutive cycles of alternating 365 nm and 590 nm irradiation, 1 preserved its photoswitchable behavior (). However, fluorescence decay and enhancement were observed to occur at different rates (). For instance, a sample of 1 irradiated at 365 nm for 30 min required 107 min of irradiation at 590 nm to regain its fluorescence response (Figure ). This fact is consistent with the photoisomerization rates that we observed for noncoordinated BPMTC in the solid state. Indeed, conversion of BPMTC from the closed form to the open form under 590 nm irradiation is ~45 times slower than the reverse process.

elements.content: (a) Emission spectra recorded for 1, scaled to give a peak intensity (I 0) of 1.0 on the first scan at λex = 590 nm. The inset shows epifluorescence microscopy images of a crystal of 1 at λex = 370 nm (left) and 510 nm (right). (b) Time-dependent fluorescence response of Zn2(ZnTCPP) irradiated at 365 nm for 25 min. (c) Emission spectra recorded for Zn2(ZnTCPP) (λex = 590 nm) analogously to 1. The first emission spectrum of Zn2(ZnTCPP) is highlighted in red.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Emission spectra recorded for 1, scaled to give a peak intensity (I 0) of 1.0 on the first scan at λex = 590 nm. The inset shows epifluorescence microscopy images of a crystal of 1 at λex = 370 nm (left) and 510 nm (right). (b) Time-dependent fluorescence response of Zn2(ZnTCPP) irradiated at 365 nm for 25 min. (c) Emission spectra recorded for Zn2(ZnTCPP) (λex = 590 nm) analogously to 1. The first emission spectrum of Zn2(ZnTCPP) is highlighted in red.

elements.content: To estimate the extent of fluorescence quenching accessible in 1, the sample was irradiated for 50 min at λex = 365 nm, which resulted in 60% modulation depth. The rate constant for fluorescence decay (I/I 0, where I 0 is the maximum of the emission intensity at 653 nm) was calculated by fitting the decay with a monoexponential function and found to be 10–3 s–1 (). It is important to note that the PXRD analysis showed preservation of MOF integrity after sample irradiation (), which allowed us to exclude MOF degradation as a possible cause of the changes in the fluorescence profile of 1.
elements.clean_text: To estimate the extent of fluorescence quenching accessible in 1, the sample was irradiated for 50 min at λex = 365 nm, which resulted in 60% modulation depth. The rate constant for fluorescence decay (I/I 0, where I 0 is the maximum of the emission intensity at 653 nm) was calculated by fitting the decay with a monoexponential function and found to be 10-3 s-1 (). It is important to note that the PXRD analysis showed preservation of MOF integrity after sample irradiation (), which allowed us to exclude MOF degradation as a possible cause of the changes in the fluorescence profile of 1.

elements.content: To describe quantitatively the ET processes occurring in 1, we sought an independent measurement of the ET efficiency Φe based on the time-resolved fluorescence decay lifetimes (). Time-resolved decays for 1 and Zn2(ZnTCPP) under 360 nm excitation () clearly demonstrated more rapid decay of 1 compared with Zn2(ZnTCPP) over most of the acquisition time. Analysis of the curves with a reconvolution fit () supported triexponential decays in each case, with the longer two lifetimes moving to significantly shorter values in 1, contributing to a shortening of the amplitude-weighted average lifetime from 1.46 to 1.24 ns, which corresponds to Φe = 15% and an estimated ET rate constant (k e) of 1.2 × 1010 s–1.
elements.clean_text: To describe quantitatively the ET processes occurring in 1, we sought an independent measurement of the ET efficiency Φe based on the time-resolved fluorescence decay lifetimes (). Time-resolved decays for 1 and Zn2(ZnTCPP) under 360 nm excitation () clearly demonstrated more rapid decay of 1 compared with Zn2(ZnTCPP) over most of the acquisition time. Analysis of the curves with a reconvolution fit () supported triexponential decays in each case, with the longer two lifetimes moving to significantly shorter values in 1, contributing to a shortening of the amplitude-weighted average lifetime from 1.46 to 1.24 ns, which corresponds to Φe = 15% and an estimated ET rate constant (k e) of 1.2 × 1010 s-1.

elements.content: To address the possibility of RET in 1, the Förster critical radius (R 0) was estimated through calculation of the spectral overlap function between the Zn2(ZnTCPP) donor and the closed-form switch acceptor, which was found to be J = 4.1 × 10–14 cm–6 (; see the for more details). Notably, the DR spectrum of BPMTC in the solid state is red-shifted in comparison with absorption in solution, and this fact was used as a rough approximation for the calculations. If this shift is included in the spectral overlap calculation, a larger estimate for R 0 results. For instance, we estimated that a 25 nm bathochromic shift leads to a 1.8-fold increase in J (). On the basis of the calculated J, we estimated R 0 to be 30 Å (), which is far beyond the D–A distance approximated from the structural data (e.g., the distance between Zn in the ZnTCPP unit and the corresponding N···N centroid is ∼9 Å). Therefore, RET could be responsible for the observed changes in the emission profile of 1.
elements.clean_text: To address the possibility of RET in 1, the Förster critical radius (R 0) was estimated through calculation of the spectral overlap function between the Zn2(ZnTCPP) donor and the closed-form switch acceptor, which was found to be J = 4.1 × 10-14 cm-6 (; see the  for more details). Notably, the DR spectrum of BPMTC in the solid state is red-shifted in comparison with absorption in solution, and this fact was used as a rough approximation for the calculations. If this shift is included in the spectral overlap calculation, a larger estimate for R 0 results. For instance, we estimated that a 25 nm bathochromic shift leads to a 1.8-fold increase in J (). On the basis of the calculated J, we estimated R 0 to be 30 Å (), which is far beyond the D-A distance approximated from the structural data (e.g., the distance between Zn in the ZnTCPP unit and the corresponding N⋅⋅⋅N centroid is ~9 Å). Therefore, RET could be responsible for the observed changes in the emission profile of 1.

elements.content: The foregoing results demonstrate that BPMTC retains photochromic properties after coordinative immobilization in a MOF matrix. The reversible response of BPMTC to optical control inputs was used to switch the emission properties of the parent framework by activation of the ET process. This system simultaneously embodies visible-light harvesting and ET governed by photoswitchable spectral overlap in an array of chromophores with well-defined distances and angles and sufficient structural integrity to permit multiple transformation cycles. This demonstrates and extends the role that a MOF can play as a versatile platform to alter or preserve the ligand photophysical properties. The concept demonstrated here could foreshadow the utilization of photochromic ligands to direct chromophore behavior in large light-harvesting ensembles.
elements.clean_text: The foregoing results demonstrate that BPMTC retains photochromic properties after coordinative immobilization in a MOF matrix. The reversible response of BPMTC to optical control inputs was used to switch the emission properties of the parent framework by activation of the ET process. This system simultaneously embodies visible-light harvesting and ET governed by photoswitchable spectral overlap in an array of chromophores with well-defined distances and angles and sufficient structural integrity to permit multiple transformation cycles. This demonstrates and extends the role that a MOF can play as a versatile platform to alter or preserve the ligand photophysical properties. The concept demonstrated here could foreshadow the utilization of photochromic ligands to direct chromophore behavior in large light-harvesting ensembles.

elements.content: Experimental details; X-ray structure refinement table and crystallographic data (CIF); NMR, MS, TGA, IR, EDX, and PXRD data; lifetime decays; and calculated spectral overlap integrals. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Experimental details; X-ray structure refinement table and crystallographic data (CIF); NMR, MS, TGA, IR, EDX, and PXRD data; lifetime decays; and calculated spectral overlap integrals. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content: Among the variety of photochromic molecules, diaryl­ethene-based compounds were chosen for immobilization inside the MOF matrix because of their fatigue-resistant photochromic performance. Moreover, diarylethene derivatives are thermally stable and exhibit rapid response in the solid state. For incorporation into a framework, a diarylethene-based core was modified with two pyridyl arms to facilitate coordination to a metal center (Scheme ). The photochromic molecule of choice dictates the selection of the paired photoluminescent MOF, which should satisfy two main criteria. First, the emission spectrum of the MOF (D) should overlap with the absorption spectrum of the closed form of BPMTC (A) for effective resonance energy transfer (RET). Second, the emissive framework should possess accessible metal sites for efficient BPMTC pillar installation. The two-dimensional (2D) framework Zn2(ZnTCPP) [H4TCPP = tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin] satisfies both requirements. Figure demonstrates that Zn2(ZnTCPP) is emissive in the range of 600–700 nm with an emission maximum of 652 nm (λex = 590 nm). As a result, the fluorescence spectrum of Zn2(ZnTCPP) overlaps with the absorption profile of BPMTC in the closed form but does not overlap with the absorption spectrum of the photoswitch in the open form (Figure ). Thus, irradiation of the Zn2(ZnTCPP)–BPMTC framework with UV or visible light could result in quenching or enhancement of the MOF fluorescence, respectively (Scheme ). Furthermore, Zn2(ZnTCPP) also fulfills the second criterion (vide supra). Its structure consists of 2D sheets made from paddlewheel Zn2(O2C−)4 secondary building units (SBUs) bridged by ZnTCPP4– ligands [Figures S1 and S2 in the (SI)]. Each SBU contains two Zn atoms with axially coordinated solvent molecules, which can be replaced with pyridine-containing pillars.

The two-dimensional (2D) framework Zn2(ZnTCPP) [H4TCPP = tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin] satisfies both requirements. Figure  demonstrates that Zn2(ZnTCPP) is emissive in the range of 600-700 nm with an emission maximum of 652 nm (λex = 590 nm). As a result, the fluorescence spectrum of Zn2(ZnTCPP) overlaps with the absorption profile of BPMTC in the closed form but does not overlap with the absorption spectrum of the photoswitch in the open form (Figure ). Thus, irradiation of the Zn2(ZnTCPP)-BPMTC framework with UV or visible light could result in quenching or enhancement of the MOF fluorescence, respectively (Scheme ). Furthermore, Zn2(ZnTCPP) also fulfills the second criterion (vide supra). Its structure consists of 2D sheets made from paddlewheel Zn2(O2C-)4 secondary building units (SBUs) bridged by ZnTCPP4- ligands [Figures S1 and S2 in the  (SI)]. Each SBU contains two Zn atoms with axially coordinated solvent molecules, which can be replaced with pyridine-containing pillars.

cln_elements.content: Diffuse reflectance (DR) spectra of BPMTC in the closed (blue trace) and open (black trace) forms, normalized to a value of 1.0 at 339 nm. Gray lines correspond to DR spectra collected during irradiation of BPMTC at 365 nm. The red trace depicts the normalized emission spectrum of Zn2(ZnTCPP) (λex = 590 nm). The inset shows a photograph of BPMTC after irradiation at 365 and 590 nm.

cln_elements.content: PXRD patterns of 1 and simulated Zn2(ZnTCPP) (preferential orientation along the 00l direction). The unit cell parameters of Zn2(ZnTCPP) and 1 were determined by single-crystal X-ray crystallography.
